html:
• anchor

    Photo: © Tom Harris

    Spelman College is continuing its great history of contributions to the intellectual life of Atlanta for the 144th year with the help of a new building project from Studio Gang. 

    The $96 million Mary Schmidt Campbell Center for Innovation and the Arts (CI&A) supports the all-women’s liberal arts college’s academic programs in filmmaking, dance, theater, and musical performances with new technology suites and other STEM-minded educational spaces. 

    This is an 82,500-square-foot building located across from campus, fronting Westview Drive adjacent to the fine arts departments' current home in the Milligan Building. 

    State-of-the-art labs, classrooms, and other education spaces in its program are arranged around a skylight-framed central atrium called the Forum that serves as the arbiter of a host of different activities. Each overlaps in such a way so as to challenge students to interact and collaborate outside their respective disciplines. 

    Patterned sunshades and layers of screen filters are used on the upper levels to provide thermal protection and solar shading while reducing energy use, glare, and the mechanical load of the building. 

    On the recessed ground level, a shaded set of 'porches' are included that provide open-air areas for studying, dining, and gathering, and a lobby that can host performances, lectures, and exhibitions. 

    The ground-floor Arthur M. Blank Innovation Lab is enclosed by glazing at the southwest corner. Studio Gang says they preferred Flemish bonded brick as the main facade material in homage to endemic red Georgian clay, while, further up the volume, "flat metal panels on the upper volume give the building a contemporary character that reflects the innovation happening there."

    Its status and placement as the first building to go beyond the gates of the 39-acre campus is a critical factor in what the firm and college said helps establish a stronger connection to Spelman’s Westside neighbors. 

    More importantly, the Center (which is the first new academic facility at Spelman in nearly 25 years) helps to stem the tide of under-investment in HBCU campus architecture and facilities that has recently been addressed through large capital campaigns spurred in part by a $17 billion commitment from the Biden Administration.

    Spelman's interim president, Rosalind "Roz" Brewer, says finally: "This is not just a building – it is a statement of our ongoing commitment to excellence, modernization and community impact."

    The project joins recent higher ed designs for Harvard, the University of Kentucky, and California College of the Arts that all reached major milestones within the past year.
